journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Optimization of a phase stabilization controller for an ultra-precision positioning stage using a structured genetic algorithm

contrib-group.aff: Department of Precision Instruments and Mechanology, Tsinghua University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Jin Yang, State Key Laboratory of Tribology, Department of Precision Instruments and Mechanology, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, People’s Republic of China. Email: j-y07@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn

abstract.p: A practical controller optimization method is proposed to improve control performance in response speed and positioning accuracy of an ultra-precision positioning stage. The structural resonance characteristics as well as the time delay effect severely limit the control bandwidth, and the direct drive feature enabled by aerostatic bearing and voice coil motors makes the stage very sensitive to various disturbances. Therefore, a phase stabilization controller is employed owing to its superior performance in suppressing resonances compared with a traditional notch-based controller. By developing candidates of controller structure based on phase stabilization design criteria, the controller design involves the determination of both structure and parameters, which can achieve better performance than merely tuning parameters of a controller with predefined structure. Consequently, the design of structure and parameters of the controller are formulated into an optimization problem, and the objective function considers both control bandwidth and disturbance rejection to obtain balanced improvements of both response speed and positioning accuracy. Then a structured genetic algorithm is applied to optimize the structure and parameters of the controller simultaneously. Experiments are carried out for comparison of the proposed strategy with the traditional notch-based proportional–integral–derivative controller and the manually tuned phase stabilization controller. Comparative experimental results validate that the optimized controller achieves the smallest positioning error and shortest settling time, which demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method in practical application.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ultra-precision equipment such as wafer steppers and scanners, scanning tunneling microscopes, and precision machine tools are mostly concerned with high-speed/high-acceleration motion with nanometer-scaled positioning and tracking precision. At present, dual stage configurations are widely used to satisfy the extreme specifications, and multiple degrees-of-freedom (DOF) positioning stages supported by air static bearings and driven by voice coil motors are usually used as the final positioning device. Air bearing enables frictionless motion and the voice coil motors guarantee high linearity of driven forces and rapid dynamics, which are very beneficial in achieving the desired high precision. However the stage also exhibits unpleasant characteristics such as resonances caused by structural flexibility and time delay due to sampling and electrical parts. These characteristics are detrimental to the closed-loop stability and limit the control bandwidth. To achieve the desired high performance, many researchers have resorted to advanced controller designs such as linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG), H-infinity (H∞), and mu (µ) synthesis in the control of various kinds of precision positioning stage.1–3 Theoretically, these methods can develop optimal controllers in standard frameworks according to predefined performance weights. However it is difficult to determine the weights properly, and thus the resultant controllers are not actually optimal. In addition, the controllers are often of high order and not easy for practical implementation.

Due to the practical limitations of the LQG, H∞, and µ controllers, classical proportional–integral–derivative (PID) and loop shaping controllers are still the most widely used in the control of precision positioning stages.4–7 When the stage contains mechanical resonances, one or more notch filters are cascaded with the controller to stabilize the resonances. The advantages of these classical methods are obvious: the tuning of parameters is well understood, and the resultant controller is of low order and easy to implement. However the performances achieved rely significantly on the experience of the designer. Research into the control of hard disk drivers, which are another kind of precision positioning device, shows that phase stabilization controllers could improve positioning performance compared with notch-based controllers.8–10 Unfortunately the tuning of phase stabilization controllers is not a trivial task, and needs more experience than notch-based controllers.

In order to reduce dependence on the skill of the designer, optimization algorithms are introduced to optimize the parameters of controllers.11–14 Current traditional gradient-based optimization algorithms can only handle controllers with a very simple structure such as PID controllers. In many research works, global probability search algorithms such as genetic algorithm (GA) and particle swarm optimization (PSO) are proposed to optimize more complex controllers.15–19 GA and PSO have good global searching capabilities and do not have any restriction on the objective function. Thus, designers can choose any complex objective functions and arbitrarily structured controllers. In addition, structured genetic algorithm (SGA), which is an extension of standard GA and possesses additional structural optimization capability, is proposed to optimize the structure and parameters of the controller simultaneously.20,21

In the present work, a practical controller optimization scheme for an ultra-precision positioning stage is studied. The stage suffers from mechanical resonances and time delay due to the characteristics of structural and electrical elements, and also the stage is very sensitive to disturbances as it is supported by air bearing and driven by voice coil motors. All of these characteristics impose great difficulties for achieving the desired rapid response and high positioning accuracy performance. In order to solve the problem, the controller optimization is based on phase stabilization instead of notch-based design. Candidates of controller structure are developed based on phase stabilization design criteria, and thus the determination of both structure and parameters of the controller is considered. This makes the controller design more flexible and the performance achieved is better than when merely tuning parameters of a controller with fixed structure. However, this also makes the design much more difficult. Thus the controller design is formulated into an optimization problem, and SGA is utilized especially to find the best structure and parameters of the controller simultaneously for its structural and parametric optimization capability. The optimized controller is compared with two manually tuned controllers through experiments designed to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

sec.title: Precision positioning stage and its dynamic characteristics
sec.p: Figure 1 is a photograph of the precision positioning stage system studied. The stage is driven by four moving magnet planar voice coil motors and supported by an aerostatic bearing, and can move almost without any friction in three planar DOF, i.e. x-translation, y-translation, and z-rotation. Figure 2 gives a detailed view of the structure of the stage in an exploded plot. The four voice coil motors are placed orthogonally as shown in Figure 3. The two voice coil motors in the x-direction are connected in series and the two voice coil motors in the y-direction are controlled independently, so that all three DOF of the mover can be actively controlled. The corresponding travel ranges of the three DOF are about 2 mm×2 mm×20 mrad. Three laser interferometers are used to measure the position of the mover, and a VME bus-based industrial computer is used to control the stage.

caption.p: Photograph of the precision stage system.
Exploded view of the stage.
The arrangement of voice coil motors.

sec.p: Assuming the stage is ideally rigid and neglecting the dynamics of the current amplifiers, the stage can be decoupled to three independent single-input/single-output (SISO) systems with static input and output transformations, and each is a double integrator, as
Therefore three independent SISO controllers can be designed and applied. In this study only control of the y-direction model is considered for simplicity.

Due to the mechanical flexibility, the dynamics of the current amplifiers, sampling, etc., the decoupled models are far more complex than the double integrator in equation (1). Figures 4 and 5 respectively show the Bode plot and Nyquist plot of the measured frequency response and the fitted parametric model of the y-direction model. Two resonances around 960 Hz and 1380 Hz can be identified in the magnitude plot. In addition, considerable phase lag in the middle frequency range can be seen from the phase plot, which implies the existence of time delay in the system. The resonance located at 960 Hz is a major devastating factor for stability, while the other insignificant resonance will not cause much trouble. Besides, the phase lag property may also lead to instability. Thus, these characteristics should be carefully handled in the controller design.

caption.p: Bode plot of measured frequency response and fitted parametric model.
Nyquist plot of measured frequency response and fitted parametric model.

sec.title: Phase stabilization controller design
sec.p: The resonance characteristics are one major detrimental factor for closed-loop instability. Traditionally, notch filters are used to stabilize the resonances by keeping the peaks of resonances below 0 dB, and this is also called amplitude stabilization. Besides, phase stabilization also could be used to suppress resonances. Compared with notch-based design, phase stabilization can help to improve the control performance while decreasing the robustness with respect to model uncertainty. Considering that the obtained stage model is quite accurate, phase stabilization can be used to improve the performance.

sec.title: Stability criteria for phase stabilization design
sec.p: Phase stabilization utilizes the phase characteristics rather than amplitude characteristics of the open loop to keep the closed loop stable. According to the Nyquist stability criterion, the control loop is stable if the Nyquist plot of the open-loop function does not encircle or pass through the critical point (–1, 0j). Therefore, the resonance which is located on the right half plane on the Nyquist plot will not harm the closed-loop stability even if the magnitude of the resonance peak is above 0 dB. In phase stabilization design, the second phase margin is introduced to evaluate the stability of resonances.10

The second phase margin of a Nyquist plot is the angle from the negative real axis to the vector from the origin to the point where the Nyquist plot passes through a unit circle from the inside to the outside (see angles α and β in Figure 10).

The second phase margin should be at least 40° to keep robust again some variation of the damping and the natural frequency, and in that case the resonance peak will be located in the right half plane in the Nyquist plot and does not harm the closed-loop stability. Notice the second phase margin only indicates the stability of the resonances, and other loop shaping criteria such as requirements on phase margin, gain margin as well as peak of the modulus of the closed-loop sensitivity function also should be satisfied. As a rule of thumb, phase margin should not be less than 30°, and gain margin not less than 6 dB, and the peak of the modulus of the sensitivity function not more than 6 dB.

sec.title: Candidates for controller structure
sec.p: In the literature, the design of phase stabilization controllers focuses mainly on the tuning of parameters without comparison of different structures.8–10 However, according to our experience, the choice of structure may be more important than the tuning of parameters. In the present study all possible structures of the phase stabilization controller are developed based on phase stabilization criteria with consideration of the characteristics of the stage, and thus the determinations of both structure and parameters are considered in the controller design. In this way controller design is much more flexible than merely tuning parameters of a controller with predefined structured, and thus the performance should be much better.

Due to the dominant double integrators’ effects, the controller should provide enough phase lead around the bandwidth to stabilize the plant. Also the controller should contain an integrator to reject low-frequency disturbance and eliminate the steady-state error. Meanwhile special care should be taken for the stability of the resonances. As shown in Figure 5, the major resonance is on the right half plane in the Nyquist plot of the plant, which indicates that it will not cause stability problems. However, considering the phase lead of the controller, the resonance will shift to the left half plane, and consequently may lead to instability. Therefore a lag filter can be used to stabilize the major resonance by canceling the phase lead of the controller around the resonance frequency. With the above analysis, the structure of the controller can be expressed as
where CG(s) is the gain of the controller, and CI(s) is the integrator, CL(s) is the lead filter, and CR(s) is the lag filter. CG(s) is simple a gain, given as
where K is a constant. CI(s) can be chosen as

where TI is the time constant of the zero. In the literature, CL(s) is usually chosen as a first-order lead, and CR(s) is usually chosen as a first-order lag or a notch filter (but used as lag filter). However, considering the characteristics of the stage, this may not necessarily lead to satisfactory performance here. On one hand, there exists a large phase lag due to time delay, as a result of which the phase lead of a first-order lead filter may not be sufficient. On the other hand, the controller is expected to provide enough phase lead at bandwidth but less phase lead at resonance frequency to keep the prescribed phase margin and second phase margin. Therefore high-order lead and lag filters are preferred as they have better local shaping ability than low-order filters, but the order should also not be too high as the total order of the controller should be restricted. Let the order of both CL(s) and CR(s) not exceed two, thus the total order of the controller will not exceed five. Then the following possible structures for CL(s) and CR(s) can be used

where

are the time constants of the first-order zeros or poles; ξLnz, ξLnp, ξRNz, and ξRnp are the damping ratios of the second-order zeros or poles; and ωLnz, ωLNp, ωRnZ, and ωRnp are the natural frequencies of the second-order zeros or poles. Both CL(s) and CR(s) have three possible structures, i.e. first-order filter, second-order filter with real poles/zeros, and second-order filter with complex poles/zeros, and the controller has nine different possible structures. Note that it is not possible to judge which structure is best in advance; thus all these nine structures should be considered.

sec.title: Formulation of controller optimization
sec.p: The design of phase stabilization controllers is less transparent than the design of notch-based controllers because the second phase margin is defined on the Nyquist plot. In addition, the design becomes even more complicated if different structures are to be considered. To make the controller design less dependent on experience and to maximize the performance, the design is formulated into an optimization problem and then an optimization algorithm is applied to find the optimal structure and parameters of the controller.

In controller design, one major factor that affects the response speed and positioning accuracy is the control bandwidth. Thus one primary objective for the controller optimization is to maximize the bandwidth ωbw, and the objective function can be given as

In this study, the bandwidth is referred to as the frequency where the open-loop transfer function crosses the 0 dB line for the first time.22 On the other hand the stage is very susceptible to disturbances because there are no friction and transmission elements between the mover and stator of the stage. In order to achieve high positioning accuracy, disturbance rejection should also be taken into account in the controller design. In the general scheme of feedback control as shown in Figure 6, the error equation is
with S(s) being the sensitivity function

where P(s) is the model of the stage, and C(s) is the controller; with r(t) being the reference input, y(t) the output of the stage, d(t) the disturbance, and n(t) the measurement noise, then R(s), Y(s), D(s), and N(s) are the Laplace transforms of r(t), y(t), d(t), and n(t), respectively. The control error caused by disturbance to the stage is

caption.p: General scheme of feedback control.

sec.p: Therefore in order to minimize the influence of disturbance, the objective function for disturbance rejection should be minimized
Combining the two objective functions in equations (7) and (11), the total optimization objective can be given as

where λ is the weight to adjust relative importance of the bandwidth and disturbance rejection. The stability criteria, such as gain margin, phase margin, peak of the modulus of sensitivity, and second phase margin, should be used as constraints of the optimization. The problem is further converted to unconstrained optimization by transforming the stability constraints to penalties, as
with

where JGm, JPm, JS, and JR are the penalties for gain margin, phase margin, peak of the modulus of sensitivity, and second phase margin, respectively. Gm is the gain margin, Pm is the phase margin, S is the peak of the modulus of sensitivity margin, and Pm2nd is the second phase margin. γG, γP, γS, and γP2nd are the lower or upper bounds for Gm, Pm, S, and Pm2nd, respectively. W is a positive constant for the penalty terms.

sec.title: Controller optimization by SGA
sec.p: The objective function in equation (13) is beyond the scope of traditional optimization problems. The objective function cannot be analytically expressed but is calculated on discrete frequency grids instead. Moreover, it involves the selection of different structures other than optimization of parameters. The former property excludes the application of traditional gradient-based algorithms, while the latter requires the optimization algorithm to be capable of structural optimization. In this study, SGA is applied as the optimization algorithm. SGA is an extension of the ordinary GA, and it has two layers of genes: the coefficient genes that encode the parameters as in ordinary GA, and the control genes that decide the activation or deactivation of specific structures. The genetic operations such as crossover and mutation are carried out independently on different genetic layers.20,21,23 This hierarchical gene architecture enables SGA to perform structural and parametric optimization simultaneously, and SGA has been successfully applied in the optimization of structure and parameters of the performance weights in H∞ controller design.20,21 Therefore, SGA is particularly suitable for this controller optimization problem.

sec.title: SGA scheme for controller optimization
sec.p: As expressed in equations (2) to (6), the controller has 9 different possible structures and 18 free parameters. The structures and parameters of the controller are encoded with control genes and coefficient genes, respectively. Real value coding is used instead of binary coding in the implementation of SGA. Real value coding does not require any encoding and decoding process, which makes the algorithm more efficient and the programming easier. The control gene gcon can be chosen as a single enumeration variable, and the relationship between the controller structure and control gene’s values is shown as Table 1. The 18 coefficient genes are chosen as float variables because all parameters of the controller are float types. Figure 7 shows the chromosome structure and the encoding of the controller structure and parameters.

caption.p: Control gene value and structures of the controller.
Chromosome structure and encoding of the controller structure and parameters.

sec.p: The design of the fitness function or the scaling of the objective function is of critical importance for the performance of the GA. Due to the large penalty terms in equation (13), the objective function values of individuals around the global optimum will be very close to each other. Consequently, linear scaling will lead to poor convergence performance as the differences in fitness are tiny when approaching convergence. The following exponential scaling is used to improve the convergence performance
where a is a system parameter for scaling.
The arithmetic crossover technique is used, and the crossover operations are carried out as24

where
X

B

are the two individuals selected for crossover operation,
X
A
t + 1
and
X
B
t + 1
are the new individuals, and α is a system parameter for crossover operation. Note the control genes should be rounded into integers.

To improve performance, in the early stage of optimization, the coefficient genes are supposed to have larger mutation jumps to fully explore the searching space; and on the other hand, smaller mutation jumps are preferred to finely tune the parameters near the end of the optimization. Thus the following non-uniform mutation strategy is used21,24

where
x
k
t
and
x
k
t + 1
are the kth old and new coefficient genes selected for mutation.
u
min
k
and
u
max
k
are the lower and upper bounds for xk, t is the current evolution number, T is the maximal generation number, b is a system parameter, and r is a uniformly distributed random number on [0, 1]. However, as the control gene gcon is enumeration type, this non-uniform mutation strategy is not applied and simple uniform mutation technique is used instead for the control gene.

The deterministic sampling selection method with elitism is used for the selection operation.24 The individuals with the best fitness of each structure are kept to the next generation without mutation and crossover operation. In addition, a special selection strategy is used to guarantee the global optimal of the solution and speed up the convergence. That is, in the early stage of the optimization, selections are restricted to the individuals with the same control gene and equivalent numbers of individuals of each structure type are selected to survive to the next generation, thus the sub-searching spaces for each structure type will be equivalently explored to prevent premature convergence; and at the end of the optimization, selections are operated on the whole population, thus the population will be dominated by the individuals corresponding to the best structure type and speed up the convergence.

sec.title: Run parameters for optimization
sec.p: The controller optimization needs the actual disturbance spectrum of the system. It can be modeled from the positioning error signal without reference input. Neglecting the measurement noise in equation (8), the disturbance spectrum can be calculated by

In order to reduce the error caused by the neglect of measurement noise, a low-gain controller is used to make the positioning error significantly larger than the measurement noise. Actually the positioning error is up to several micrometers, so that the nanometer-scaled measurement noise of laser interferometer is indeed negligible. Figure 8 shows the Bode magnitude plot of the disturbance spectrum calculated by equation (21).

caption.p: Disturbance spectrum.

sec.p:
The value of λ in equation (12) which is used as a trade-off between the objectives of bandwidth and disturbance rejection is also critical for the optimization result. As a general rule, a good value of λ will make the two parts in equation (12) about the same magnitude. Therefore, it can be determined on the assumption that equivalent improvements in bandwidth and disturbance rejection on the basis of a pre-designed benchmark controller are desired. In the case of a well-tuned notch-based PID controller (Cnotch in the section “Experiment results”), the bandwidth index ωbw=186 Hz, and the disturbance rejection index

. Note this is not rigorous but just gives a rough range for the value of λ, and in optimization λ is set to 500.

The values for bounds of stability margins in equations (14) to (17) are shown in Table 2, and they are slightly tighter than the commonly used limits in manual loop shaping. This is reasonable considering that in manual design the stability margins will not reach the limits, while the optimization result often lies on the border of constraints. However, a rather large phase margin is deliberately required to raise closed-loop damping so as to reduce overshoot.25

caption.p: Bounds of stability margins for optimization.

sec.p:
The search domain of parameters is chosen in the following way. First, manually design controllers corresponding to the candidate structures which just need to be stable, and denote the parameters set as
X
0
. Then the searching space for the parameters is set as
[ 0 . 5

, which gives enough room for searching the optimal parameters for the controller.

The selection operations are restricted within each structure when
r / T < 0 . 5
, and free selections among the whole population are carried out when
0 . 5 ≤ r / T ≤ 1
and parameter α for crossover in equation (19) is chosen as an independent random number on [0, 1], and b = 1 is used for the non-uniform mutation parameter in equation (20). Further, the maximal number of generation is set to 100. Several test runs have been carried out to find the best parameters for the scaling parameter a, population size, crossover probability, and mutation probability, and results show that a and population size influence the optimization result greatly, while crossover probability and mutation probability have minor influence and are set to 0.8 and 0.3, respectively. Table 3 shows the results of 10 runs with different values of a under a population size of 900, and Table 4 shows the results with different population size while a = 10 is used. Thus a = 10 and population size = 900 are used as the best parameters, and the best result out of the 10 runs is used as the optimum. The convergence curve is given in Figure 9, and the corresponding controller is

caption.p: Summary of optimization results for different values of scaling parameter a.
Summary of results for different population sizes
Convergence curve of the optimization.

sec.p: The optimized controller has both second-order lead and lag filters with complex poles/zeros. Because of the structural and parametric optimization capability of SGA, the optimized controller not only has the best parameters but also the best structure among the nine different candidate structures.

sec.title: Experiment results
sec.p: To evaluate the performance of the optimized controller, it is compared with two manually tuned controllers, i.e. a notch-based PID controller Cnotch and a manually tuned phase stabilization controller Cps. Cnotch consists of one integrator, one first-order lead, and one notch; and Cps consists of one integrator, two first-order leads, and one first-order lag. The parameters of Cnotch and Cps are carefully tuned to maximize the bandwidth while satisfying the stability bounds listed in Table 2. The Nyquist plot of open-loop functions and Bode plot of sensitivity functions corresponding to each controller are shown in Figures 10 and 11.

caption.p: Nyquist plot of open-loop functions with different controllers.
Bode plot of sensitivity functions with different controllers.

sec.p: The controllers are digitalized by Tustin transformation and implemented in the control system. Step input and stand still experiments are carried out to evaluate the performance of each controller.

Figure 12 shows the responses of 1000 nm step input, and Figure 13 shows the enlarged view of settling process of the step response. The rising times corresponding to Cnotch, Cps, and Copt are 3.3 ms, 1.2 ms, and 1.3 ms, respectively, and the performance of Copt is slightly worse than that of Cps. However Copt shows much better performance in settling time than the other two controllers. From Figure 11 large low-frequency vibrations can be identified in the settling process when the stage is controlled by Cnotch and Cps, while the situation is much better with Copt. The settling times corresponding to each controller are 8.8 ms, 74.0 ms, and 6.0 ms with ±5% tolerance band (± 50 nm), and 154.8 ms, 86.4 ms, and 20.6 ms with ± 2% tolerance band (± 20 nm). On the other hand, the overshoot with Copt is about 19.3% and much larger than that with Cnotch and Cps, which are 7.7% and 3.3%, respectively, but the overshoot is still acceptable in the sense of engineering practice. Moreover, the experiments are carried out just with feedback control and the overshoot will decrease if feedforward is used.

caption.p: Step responses of the stage with different controllers.
Enlarged plot of the settling process of step responses with different controllers.

sec.p: Figures 14 and 15 present the time plots and histogram plots of positioning errors, respectively. Again the optimized controller outperforms the other two controllers. The positioning errors (3σ) are 5.31 nm, 4.40 nm, and 4.02 nm, respectively.

caption.p: Time plot of positioning error of the stage with different controllers.
Histogram of the positioning error with different controllers.

sec.p: The experimental results are summarized in Table 5. It can be concluded that the optimized controller prominently improves control performance in response speed and positioning accuracy of the stage.

caption.p: Summary of performance with different controllers.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, a practical controller optimization method has been proposed to improve the performance in response speed and positioning accuracy of a precision positioning stage. The characteristics of mechanical resonances and time delay of the stage model potentially threaten the closed-loop stability, while the direct drive characteristic enabled by the air bearing and voice coil motors makes the stage very sensitive to disturbances. The controller optimization is based on phase stabilization instead of notch-based design to improve the performance. All possible candidates of controller structure have been given by phase stabilization design criteria with the consideration the characteristics of the stage, and thus the design of both structure and parameters of the controller has been considered, which can achieve better performance than merely tuning the parameters of a controller with predefined structure. To optimize the performance and make the design less dependent on experience at the same time, the design of both structure and parameters of the controller has been converted to an optimization problem, and both bandwidth and disturbance rejection have been considered in the objective function to achieve the desired performance. In particular, SGA, which has both structural and parametric optimization capability, has been utilized to optimize the structure and parameters of the controller simultaneously. Comparative experimental results show that significant improvements have been achieved in settling time and positioning accuracy with the optimized controller, which validates the effectiveness of the proposed method in practical application.
